head.title: Nostalgic Sites to Cruise Along the Internet Highway

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Sales and Business Development

hedline.hl1: Nostalgic Sites to Cruise Along the Internet Highway

abstract.p: Internet market in nostalgic cars explained (M)

block.p: WHEN General Motors, the world's largest automaker, recently announced a joint venture with its dealers to establish a Web site offering cars online, it was following in the footsteps of dealers in classic cars.

''The Internet has been absolutely overwhelming for us,'' said Roy Sayles, the owner of VIP Classics, a classic car dealer in San Diego. ''We get 4,000 hits a day.'' The Web site, www.vipclassics.com, which started about five years ago, Mr. Sayles said, ''has probably tripled our sales.''

In fact, dealers and classic car enthusiasts have created a vast collection of Internet options. With ''classic cars'' as a search term, Google's Webometer clocks 75,900 matches in 0.5 seconds. So how is a true lover of the glorious fins of the '59 Chevy, the comforting bulges of a '67 Volkswagen Beetle or the majesty of the '62 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud expected to maneuver through all that traffic?
Take heart. First, there are a few landmarks. You cannot miss the site created by Hemmings Motor News, the huge and definitive magazine on the subject, based in Bennington, Vt.

The site, www.hemmings.com, lists more than 9,000 car clubs, has a price checker, classified advertisements and a legislative alert along with appropriate lobbying groups. (Lobbying for what? Well, classic cars often cannot meet current emission standards, for one thing.) There is also a slightly cumbersome search engine for event listings, and a list of stolen cars, searchable by vehicle identification number, state of registration, or make and model.

ClassicNet at www.motorlit.com/classicnet, another landmark, collects links to groups dedicated to specific makes or models of cars, from Corvettes to microcars. And one option at Deja.com, www.deja.com/usenet, allows users to type in key words and search for matches through recent postings.
Another possible route through the Internet, one that offers some fascinating detours, is to rev up a search engine and scan for matches.

A photo gallery of wrecks called Junkyards of North Georgia, www.autohobbydigest.com/salvage.html, showed up on a Yahoo search, as does a guide to buying and protecting classic cars, www.kennish.com /securecar, created by a security consultant, John W. Kennish. (Other pages on his paranoia-provoking site include Preparing for Bomb Threats and The ATM.)

There is yet one more way to navigate the otherwise undifferentiated mass of Web offerings. Caution: This method is said to be most unpleasant for 49 percent of the population. It's called asking directions.

If this drastic action must be taken, the right source would be someone who knows classic cars and the Internet. Someone like Mike Lascualo, a Colorado resident who keeps a gallery of his classic cars at www.mrdos.com/cars.htm and who owns a 1959 Impala, a 1961 Impala and a 1962 Bel Air station wagon. ''And I almost have a 1960 Pontiac Bonneville,'' Mr. Lascualo said. He described his day job as ''an S.Q.L. server D.B.A.,'' which he translated as ''computer geek.''
One of his favorite sites, he said, is The Gold Book at www.manheimgold.com/index
